items.title: K'gari traditional owners raise issues with dingo management after teen's death
items.description: The body of Piper James, 19, was found surrounded by dingoes on a beach on the island's eastern coast, but how she died may not be known for some time.

items.title: Weather disaster deaths decline despite climate change, study finds

featured_image.name: Multiple death counts for climate-related disasters : NPR

items.description:
As climate change intensifies extreme weather events around the world, a paradox has emerged: overall mortality from weather-related disasters has declined in recent decades, even as storms, floods, and heatwaves grow more frequent and severe.

An analysis by AFP of data from EM-DAT, a global disaster database run by the Belgium-based Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters (CRED), found that more than 2.3 million people died from weather-related events between 1970 and 2025. The death toll from 2015 to 2025 reached 305,156, a notable decline from 354,428 in the previous decade.[1][2][3]

"It's not because the events haven't become more dangerous. It's because we have become a lot better at coping with them," Dr. Marina Romanello, executive director of the Lancet Countdown, told AFP.[3]

items.title: Landing attempt aborted after trespass incident at Melbourne Airport
items.description: A pilot is forced to abort a landing attempt at Melbourne Airport, and two take-offs are delayed after an alleged late-night trespassing incident.

items.title: Why Emmanuel Macron wore sunglasses to Davos
items.description: The French president's appearance at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum makes headlines, but not for any policy reasons.

items.title: 'Running a global mafia': Facing the reality of Trump's changing world view
items.description: As Donald Trump celebrates one year of his second term in the White House, he is rewriting all the rules for global order, and no-one seems ready to stop his "imperial ambitions".

items.title: Study finds ChatGPT systematically favors wealthy Western nations

featured_image.name: The Silicon Gaze': ChatGPT rankings skew toward rich Western ...

items.description:
When prompted with subjective questions comparing places around the world, OpenAI's ChatGPT systematically favors wealthier, Western regions while ranking much of the Global South at the bottom, according to new research published Tuesday.

The study, titled "The Silicon Gaze: A typology of biases and inequality in LLMs through the lens of place," analyzed more than 20 million queries submitted to ChatGPT's 4o-mini model. Researchers from the Oxford Internet Institute at the University of Oxford and the University of Kentucky found that the chatbot repeatedly ranked high-income countries, including the United States, Western Europe, and parts of East Asia, as "better," "smarter," "happier," and "more innovative" than poorer regions.[1][2]

items.title: How Australia will mark the National Day of Mourning for Bondi victims
items.description: Thursday will be a national day of mourning for the victims of the Bondi Beach terror attack. Here's what you need to know.

items.title: Trump demands NATO allies spend 5 percent of GDP, doubts their support

featured_image.name: Trump Announces New European Tariffs in Greenland Standoff; Allies Outraged

items.description:
President Donald Trump used the one-year anniversary of his second term to renew calls for NATO allies to meet the alliance's 5% GDP defense spending commitment, while casting doubt on whether European partners would fulfill their mutual defense obligations. His remarks come amid escalating tensions over his campaign to acquire Greenland from Denmark.

"I have done more for NATO than anyone else," Trump said during a White House briefing Tuesday. "The big fear I have with NATO is we spend tremendous amounts of money with NATO, and I know we'll come to their rescue, but I really do question whether or not they'll come to ours."[1][2]

items.title: Venezuela receives $300M from US-controlled oil sales

featured_image.name: Delcy Rodriguez Delivers A Government Report At The National Assembly

items.description:
Venezuela's acting president Delcy Rodríguez announced on Tuesday that the country has received $300 million from the sale of Venezuelan crude oil facilitated by Washington, funds she intends to use to stabilize the country's battered currency and protect workers from inflation.

"We must inform you that we have received funds from the sale of oil, and of the first $500 million, we received 300 million," Reuters quoted Rodríguez as saying during a visit to a commune base in Caracas. The interim leader stated the revenues would be used "to stabilize" the foreign exchange market "to protect the income and purchasing power of our workers".[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Australia's NATO envoy is returning home with a warning about North Korea
items.description: Australia's outgoing military envoy to NATO is preparing to return to Canberra after two years in the role, and she is coming home with a warning.

items.title: SpaceX prepares Ship 39 for Starship Flight 12 debut

featured_image.name: SpaceX preps Starship, Super Heavy for another week of ...

items.description:
SpaceX is accelerating preparations for an ambitious year that could include the company's first uncrewed mission to Mars, while simultaneously advancing Starship development and maintaining a rapid pace of satellite launches.

The company is targeting a Starship launch to Mars during the November-December 2026 planetary alignment window, which would represent the first private company mission to another planet. CEO Elon Musk has estimated a 50% chance of meeting the 2026 deadline, with plans to send Tesla Optimus humanoid robots on the initial missions to "prepare the way for humans."[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Canadian PM Mark Carney speaks out against Trump at the World Economic Forum
items.description: Canadian PM Mark Carney told the World Economic Forum "middle powers must act together".

items.title: Canada models guerrilla warfare response to US invasion

featured_image.name: Canada prepping response to hypothetical US military invasion for first time in a century, report says

items.description:
The Canadian Armed Forces have modeled a hypothetical U.S. military invasion of Canada and potential responses employing unconventional warfare tactics, The Globe and Mail reported on Tuesday, marking the first time in approximately 100 years that such scenarios have been war-gamed by Canada's military.

According to two senior government officials who spoke to The Globe and Mail, military planners are simulating a U.S. invasion from the south, anticipating American forces could overwhelm Canada's strategic defenses on land and at sea within as little as two days. The officials emphasized, however, that a U.S. invasion remains highly improbable.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Webb telescope captures dying star's fate and black hole's feeding

featured_image.name: ESA - Webb reveals Helix Nebula in glistening detail

items.description: NASA released stunning new images from the James Webb Space Telescope on Tuesday, including a detailed look at the Helix Nebula that offers a glimpse into the eventual fate of our own Sun. Meanwhile, separate observations captured a supermassive black hole in the Circinus Galaxy actively consuming surrounding material, overturning decades of assumptions about how such cosmic giants feed.

items.title: Trump and Putin envoys hold first talks on Ukraine at Davos
items.description:
Envoys for U.S. President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin met for approximately two hours in Davos on Tuesday to discuss a potential peace deal for Ukraine, with both sides characterizing the discussions as positive and constructive—even as key obstacles to ending Europe's deadliest conflict since World War II remain unresolved.

The meeting at "USA House" on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum brought together Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff and son-in-law Jared Kushner with Kremlin representative Kirill Dmitriev, marking the first time a senior Russian official has publicly engaged at the Swiss gathering since the forum froze ties with Moscow following the 2022 invasion of Ukraine.[1][2][3]

items.title: Live: De Minaur bounces back with to level the scores but rain has delayed play
items.description: Alex de Minaur will be hoping to be the first local to progress into the third round of the Australian Open after four other Australians have been knocked out today. Follow live.

items.title: Trump says NATO would be 'ash heap of history' without him

featured_image.name: Trump highlights NATO contributions but challenges allies' commitment

items.description:
President Donald Trump declared on Tuesday that NATO would be "in the ash heap of history" without his leadership, as European leaders rallied to oppose his push to acquire Greenland and his threat to impose escalating tariffs on eight allied nations.

"No single person, or President, has done more for NATO than President Donald J. Trump. If I didn't come along, there would be no NATO right now!!! It would have been in the ash heap of History," Trump wrote on Truth Social. In the same post, he added, "Sad, but TRUE!!!"[1][2][3]

The remarks came just hours before Trump departed for the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where European leaders assembled to present a united front against his territorial ambitions.

items.title: IAEA chief warns Iran may be declared in nuclear treaty violation

featured_image.name: Rafael Mariano Grossi at World Economic Forum 2025 (018905 ...

items.description:
As tensions between Washington and Tehran continue to escalate amid a violent crackdown on nationwide protests, arms control experts are sounding alarms about the security of Iran's near-weapons-grade uranium stockpile, warning that months of blocked inspections have created a dangerous void in international oversight.

The International Atomic Energy Agency has been unable to verify the status of an estimated 440.9 kilograms of uranium enriched to 60 percent purity—close to the roughly 90 percent considered weapons-grade—since U.S. and Israeli airstrikes struck key nuclear facilities in June 2025. That stockpile, according to IAEA standards, is theoretically enough material for 10 nuclear bombs if further enriched.[1][2][3]

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].
